The second Java file (atcoder_ABC132_A) takes a string and checks if it has exactly two distinct characters each appearing exactly twice. For example, "aabb" would be yes, but "aaab" would be no. It uses a HashMap to count occurrences and then checks the counts and the size.

The third Java file (atcoder_ABC124_C) takes a string of '0's and '1's and calculates the minimum number of changes needed to make all adjacent characters different. It does this by trying two approaches: one starting from the left and changing when duplicates are found, and another starting from the right, then taking the minimum of the two counts.

int third_program(char* input_str) {

    int len = strlen(input_str);

    if (len <2) return 0;

    // first approach: left to right.

    int count1 =0;

    char* temp1 = strdup(input_str);

    for (int i=1; i < len; i++) {

        if (temp1[i] == temp1[i-1]) {

                temp1[i] = '1';

            } else {

                temp1[i] = '0';

            }

            count1++;

        }

    }

    free(temp1);

    // second approach: right to left.

    int count2 =0;

    char* temp2 = strdup(input_str);

    for (int i = len-1; i>0; i--) {

        if (temp2[i] == temp2[i-1]) {

            if (temp2[i-1] == '1') {

                temp2[i-1] = '0';

            } else {

                temp2[i-1] = '1';

            }

            count2++;

        }

    }

    free(temp2);

    return (count1 < count2) ? count1 : count2;

}

    bool ok = true;

    for (int i=0; i<256; i++) {

        if (counts[i] >0) {

            distinct++;

            if (counts[i] !=2) {

                ok = false;

            }

        }

    }

    if (distinct ==2 && ok) {

        return "Yes";

    } else {

        return "No";

    }

}

int third_program(char* input_str) {

    int len = strlen(input_str);

    if (len <2) return 0;

    // first approach: left to right.

    int count1 =0;

    char* temp1 = strdup(input_str);

    for (int i=1; i < len; i++) {

        if (temp1[i] == temp1[i-1]) {

            // change current to opposite.

            if (temp1[i] == '0') {

                temp1[i] = '1';

            } else {

                temp1[i] = '0';

            }

            count1++;

        }

    }

    free(temp1);

    // second approach: right to left.

    int count2 =0;

    char* temp2 = strdup(input_str);

    for (int i = len-1; i>0; i--) {

        if (temp2[i] == temp2[i-1]) {

            if (temp2[i-1] == '1') {

                temp2[i-1] = '0';

            } else {

                temp2[i-1] = '1';

            }

            count2++;

        }

    }

    free(temp2);

    return (count1 < count2) ? count1 : count2;

}

int main() {

    int A, B;

    scanf("%d %d", &A, &B);

    // Compute first result.

    int first_result = compute_first(A, B);

    // Convert to string.

    char first_str[20]; // enough for integer.

    sprintf(first_str, "%d", first_result);

    // Process second program.

    char* second_output = second_program(first_str);

    // Now process third program with second_output.

    int final_result = third_program(second_output);

    printf("%d\n", final_result);

    return 0;

}
